docs.lead_paragraph: Several articles in the past year about the government’s plans to overhaul the health care system quoted Jonathan Gruber, identifying him as a professor of economics at M.I.T. On Friday, Professor Gruber confirmed reports that he is also a paid consultant on health care issues for the Department of Health and Human Services. Had editors been aware of his government work, the articles would have disclosed this relationship to readers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Recently we asked two policy experts of differing political persuasions why health care in America is so expensive and what the legislation emerging in Washington would or would not do about it. We posed the same question to Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance Committee and one of the leading architects of the Senate bill. Here is a condensed version of his response; the full version is posted online. ''Our health care payment system pays health care providers based on the number of treatments they perform, which creates an incentive for more care rather than better care. Insurance companies pay for every procedure a provider performs, and the more our insurance companies pay out, the more Americans are forced to pay in insurance premiums. Health reform shifts the payment system away from rewarding volume -- and toward rewarding value. And it places more emphasis on primary care and prevention, so we can stop expensive conditions before they become serious.
docs.abstract: Condensed version of Senate Finance Committee chairman Max Baucus's response to questions of why health care in America is so expensive and what emerging legislation would or would not do about it; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government released its latest estimates of health spending last week, and they allow for some telling comparisons. In 2008, the United States spent $2.3 trillion on medical care, or 16.2 percent of gross domestic product and $7,681 per person. Of this $2.3 trillion, the federal government spent $817 billion, while state and local governments spent $290 billion. The tax exclusion for employer-provided health insurance amounted to about $250 billion in lost federal revenue -- which is, effectively, a government subsidy for health care. Add up all of these sources, and you get about $1.35 trillion of health spending done by the public sector and slightly less than $1 trillion done by the private sector.
docs.abstract: Latest estimates of federal government on health spending show that US spent $2.3 trillion on medical care in 2008, 16.2 percent of gross domestic product and $7,681 per person; federal government spent $817 billion of total and state and local governments spent $290 billion; government agencies spent about $4,500 per person while private sector spent roughly $3,100 (S)
